title: What are some basic metaphysical beliefs? - Quora

response.answer_text: A metaphysical belief is a belief concerning beings in a the most general sense: a sense which includes not only the physical, spatio-temporal things that most people regard as beings, but thoughts, numbers — anything that can be said in some sense to be. Geometrical figures, angels, the soul, god. Metaphysicians, traditionally, asked questions like: what sort of beings can be said to be in a primary sense. There seems, indeed, to be a difference between the way that the individual horse is, the way the concept of horse is, and the way that the whiteness of the white horse is. Of these three, only the individual horse seems to be in a primary sense, where the other two beings are dependent on the primary sense. This, at least, is a metaphysical belief. In addition to general metaphysics, which I’ve just described, there is also special metaphysics, which concerns the specific nature of certain non-physical beings: the world (cosmology), the soul (psychology), and god (theology). Outside of Neo-Scholastic circles, though, you probably won’t find many people taking “special metaphysics” seriously. Kant pretty much killed it off. While metaphysics was believed to be dead not too long ago, it has experienced a revival of sorts, and there is now a thriving trade in “analytic” metaphysics. I’m not very fond of it, because it tends, in contrast to Aristotle, not to be grounded in an attentiveness to the way things show themselves. It is not, in other words, phenomenological. It is a question, rather, of giving a metaphysical interpretation (a model) for a formal logical construct, such as “moral logic.” Starting from the semantics of moral statements, one ends up arguing that possible worlds actually exist. I don’t really see the point in this, but then again, it’s not my thing.

“Many waters cannnot quench love, Norcan thefloods drown it, If a man wold give for love All the wealth of his hos, It would be utterly despised.” (Song of Songs, 8:7, NKJV). Love is real, whether one believes in it or has experienced it or not, and thus is an absolute, universal truth that cannot be denied successfully. “In the beginnng God created the heavens and the earth.” The mind is distinguished from the brain and man has an eternal soul or spirit that goes beyond the grave to either judgment or glory.
